docs.lead_paragraph: Senators announced today that they had reached a bipartisan agreement that resolved one of the thorniest issues in legislation to define patients' rights. Under the agreement, most employers who provide health benefits to employees would be shielded from lawsuits. The agreement, brokered by Senator Olympia J. Snowe, a moderate Republican from Maine, increased momentum for the Senate to pass the legislation this week.

headline.main: Senators Agree on Liability Limits for Patients' Rights to Sue

docs.abstract: Senators reach bipartisan agreement that resolves one of thorniest issues in legislation to define patients' rights; under agreement, most employers who provide health benefits to employees would be shielded from lawsuits; agreement is brokered by Sen Olympic J Snowe, increasing momentum for Senate to pass bill this week (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, says his 20 years as a trial lawyer left him with an unshakeable belief that ''regular folks'' deserve a level playing field in fights with corporate giants like health maintenance organizations and insurance companies. And the belief that insurance companies, in the end, respond to the bottom line. Not surprisingly, Mr. Edwards has emerged as a leading champion of giving patients a broader right to sue their H.M.O.'s, the most volatile issue in the patients' rights legislation now under debate in the Senate.

headline.main: At Center of Senate Battle, a Lawyer and a Doctor

docs.abstract: Sen John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, says his 20 years as trial lawyer leaves him with unshakeable belief that 'regular folks' deserve level playing field in fights with corporate giants like health maintenance organizations and insurance companies; he has emerged as leading champion of giving patients broader right to sue their HMO's; Sen Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, says his years as heart surgeon left him with belief that managed care has hurt doctor-patient relationship with 'haggling, bureaucratic internvention'; he firmly believes that more litigation is not way to solve problem; he is co-sponsor of rival patients' rights bill that proposes more restricted right to sue; these two men and their different views are at center of debate over what rights should be guaranteed to Americans with health insurance; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, it sometimes seemed as if every executive from traditional media who could was finding a way into cyberspace. Now, it sometimes seems as if every one of those executives who can is finding a way back. Add Patricia Fili-Krushel to the list.

headline.main: WebMD Executive Moves to AOL Time Warner

docs.abstract: Patricia Fili-Krushel, former chief executive of WebMD Corp, is named executive vice president for human resources at AOL Time Warner (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE again, the great State of New York leads the way. We've devised the ultimate in the public financing of political campaigns. Only officeholders need apply. Used to be, governors were content to stamp their names on a few billboards and buildings. Now they are television and radio celebrities. And the taxpayers pay the bills, for the privilege of seeing idyllic images of their top public servant in forests, glens and dells, and on river banks and the occasional battlefield.

headline.main: Metro Matters; Incumbency And the Face Of the State

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick column deplores Gov George E Pataki's ubiquitous presence in state-financed advertising extolling everything good about New York State; says it amounts to public financing of political campaigns for officeholders (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Senate Democrats won two significant victories today as the Senate rejected Republican challenges to provisions of a Democratic bill to define patients' rights for more than 180 million Americans. The back-to-back votes, combined with a similar vote last week, created a sense that the bill was gaining momentum, after being tied up in a partisan impasse for nearly five years.

headline.main: PATIENTS' RIGHTS PICK UP MOMENTUM IN 2 SENATE VOTES

docs.abstract: Democrats win two key victories as Senate rejects Republican challenges to provisions of patients' rights legislation; Senate, 57-43, defeats proposal to give employers complete immunity from lawsuits by employees over claims denials; measure to pull bill from floor is defeated, 61-39; co-sponsor John McCain warns tough issues remain; debate on patient litigation discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: State workers ended their 10-week rolling strike, saying they had achieved most of their objectives in the newly passed budget that Gov. Gary Locke is expected to sign. The strike by the 19,000-member Washington Federation of State Employees consisted of a series of staggered walkouts and focused on pay and health insurance. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Strike By State Workers Ends

docs.lead_paragraph: Bret D. Schundler, the crusading conservative mayor of Jersey City, soundly defeated former Representative Bob Franks in the Republican primary for governor today, setting up a sharply drawn November contest with James E. McGreevey, the Democrat. Mr. Schundler, an ardent opponent of abortion and a supporter of the rights of gun owners, who promised to lower taxes, cut government spending and take down the tollbooths on the Garden State Parkway, united both fiscal and social conservatives behind his campaign. His wide margin of victory, despite a Republican establishment united behind his opponent, gave the party's conservative wing the upper hand in the New Jersey Republican Party for the first time in 23 years.

headline.main: Schundler Wins G.O.P. Primary In New Jersey Governor's Race
headline.kicker: DECISION IN NEW JERSEY: THE OVERVIEW

docs.abstract: Bret D Schundler, conservative mayor of Jersey City, defeats former Repr Bob Franks, 57-43 percent, in New Jersey's gubernatorial primary; ardent opponent of abortion and supporter of gun-ownership rights, who also promises tax and toll cuts, draws both fiscal and social conservatives, and wins by wide margin despite party establishment's support of Franks; Pres Bush telephones congratulations; Franks calls for unity between his centrist supporters and Schundler's backers; photos of Schundler with Jack Kemp and Franks with former governor Christie Whitman; acting Gov Donald DiFrancesco, who has accused Schundler of planting news reports that forced his own withdrawal, says he does know if he will back nominee; Woodbridge Mayor James McGreevey wins Democratic nomination over token opposition (M)

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of women in their 60's, part of the surge of divorces that started a generation ago, are finding themselves forced to stay in the work force because they lack sufficient money to retire. Wages in effect are becoming their pensions. Women alone in old age have always been at greater risk of falling into poverty than have married women. But until recently, women alone generally meant widows, who at least had the pensions and savings their husbands had left them, and a tradition of living with children. Widows greatly outnumbered older divorced women until the late 1990's, but now for the first time the divorced outnumber widows.

headline.main: Lacking Pensions, Older Divorced Women Remain at Work

docs.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of women in 60's, part of surge of divorces that started generation ago, are forced to remain in labor force, lacking sufficient money to retire, and wages are becoming their pensions; labor force participation rates of women in early 60's, including those holding jobs or hunting for them, rose to record 40.1 percent in 2000, from 32.6 percent in 1981, with similar steady rise among women in their late 60's; proportion of older men in labor force, by contrast, has fallen significantly in past 30 years; as Congress prepares to debate Social Security reform, women's groups are urging that women should get credit for years at home raising children, so pensions will be greater in event of divorce; older married women are also staying on job to supplement retirement benefits of husbands, whittled down by layoffs, job shifting and pension cuts; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of women in their 60's, part of the surge of divorces that started a generation ago, are finding themselves forced to stay in the work force because they lack sufficient money to retire. Wages in effect are becoming their...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The New York Senate effort to reach a compromise over legislation mandating health insurance for contraception (news article, June 19) is flawed because it broadly exempts employers and insurers who invoke a religious objection to contraception. Federal law does not allow this.
docs.abstract: Letter from Donna Lieberman, interim exec director of New York Civil Liberties Union, holds New York State Senate effort to reach compromise over legislation mandating health insurance for contraception (June 19 news article) is flawed because it broadly exempts employers and insurers who invoke a religious objection to contraception; argues Federal law does not allow this

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As Marcia Angell (Op-Ed, June 23) implies, the country's health insurance system won't be universal unless it is compulsory, like Social Security and Medicare. As Dr. Angell says, the system will be vulnerable to dropouts if costs rise. But the solution need not entail the single-payer system that she advocates.

headline.main: Is a Patients' Rights Bill the Cure?

docs.abstract: Letter from James Tobin, Nobel laureate in economics in 1981, holds as Marcia Angell implies (June 23 Op-Ed), country's health insurance system will not be universal unless it is compulsory, like Social Security and Medicare
